newsitem.title: USA: Webster targets cost savings in merger.
newsitem.headline: Webster targets cost savings in merger.

text.p: Webster Financial Corp chief financial officer John Brennan said Tuesday the company believes it can achieve cost savings of $6 million to $7 million in the first year of its merger with DS Bancor.

Brennan said in a telephone interview cost savings would rise to more than $10 million in the second year. He said Webster calculated that it would require $4 million in annual savings to result in zero dilution.
Earlier Tuesday, Webster said in a news release that it expects the acquisition to be accretive to earnings in 1997.
Brent DiGiorgio, a spokesman for Webster, said the merger would result in branch consolidations and there would be some job eliminatons but he declined to provide any figures.
Webster, a Waterbury, Conn.-based holding company, operates 63 banking offices in central Connecticut and DS Bancor operates 23 Derby Savings Bank branches mostly in south central Connecticut.

The acquisition is expected to close in the first quarter of 1997 and to be accounted for as a pooling of interests. Webster said it expects to recognize acquisition-related charges of approximately $15 million after tax.

Webster is acquiring DS Bancor for about $137 million in a stock transaction in which DS Bancor holders will receive $43 per share in Webster common stock. The exchange ratio is subject to a "collar" adjustment depending on the level of Webster's stock.
The merger is subject to approval by the shareholders of both companies and by regulators.
Webster Financial was off 5/8 to 34-5/8 in late trading.

Analyst Kevin Timmons of First Albany Corp said some investors may be skeptical about the cost saving targets because DS Bancor, with $1.3 billion in assets, is a a fairly large acquisition for the $3.8 billion asset Webster. The analyst added, "They have a pretty big hurdle to overcome but I think they can do it."
The analyst said Webster has done about six deals in three or four years and met its targets each time.
DS Bancor was up 2-17/64 to 40-41/64 in late trading.
